questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient was posted for elective appendicectomy. He has a history of myocardial infarction and his echocardiography revealed a reduced ejection fraction.  Which of the following induction agents is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario with a history of myocardial infarction and reduced ejection fraction, etomidate is considered the most appropriate induction agent.

Etomidate is a rapid onset, intravenous anesthetic agent used for induction in patients with cardiovascular disease, reactive airway disease, and intracranial hypertension. Etomidate has minimal effect on cardiovascular function due to its lack of effect on the sympathetic nervous system and on the function of the baroreceptors. They act on alpha 2 adrenoreceptors and increase blood pressure which helps to maintain cardiovascular stability after the induction. 

It is used as a short-term sedative in hemodynamically unstable patients, like those requiring cardioversion or patients with unstable angina, for minor operative procedures. Long-term use of etomidate in trauma or terminally ill patients is not advised as there is associated adrenocortical suppression leading to reduced blood pressure.

Other options:

Option A- Ketamine has a stimulatory effect on the sympathetic nervous system and results in increased blood pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output. This leads to an increase in myocardial oxygen consumption and so it is contraindicated in ischemic heart disease.

Option C- Propofol is a myocardial depressant agent. It reduces sympathetic activity, leading to vasodilatation that results in a reduction of blood pressure and a decrease in cardiac output.

Option D- Thiopentone is also a myocardial depressant agent. It causes peripheral vasodilatation, reduction in ventricular filling, and decreased cardiac contractility. This results in a reduction in blood pressure and a decrease in cardiac output.

questions.text: A  post-cataract surgery patient came with complaints of blurring of vision for the past 2 weeks. His cataract surgery was done 3 months back. His optical coherence tomography (OCT) image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a post-cataract surgery patient presenting with a blurring of vision and an OCT image showing intraretinal cystoid spaces is suggestive of cystoid macular edema (CME).

Common causes of CME include previous cataract surgery, uveitis, central retinal vein occlusions, diabetic retinopathy, retinitis pigmentosa, and retinopathy of prematurity, and topical prostaglandins. Cystoid macular edema in post-cataract surgery patients is termed as Irvine-Gass syndrome. 

In CME, OCT shows foveal depression, intraretinal cystoid spaces, and retinal thickening.

CME occurs due to a break in the inner and outer blood-retinal barrier. Due to retinal vessel leak fluid or exudate comes out and forms cystic space in the central retina. Mostly it gets accumulated in the outer plexiform (Henle's layer) and inner nuclear layers of the retina. 

On fundoscopy, the multiple cystoid oval spaces in CME appear as a  "honeycomb appearance".

In Fundus fluorescein angiography fluid accumulation in outer plexiform, layer shows a characteristic flower petal pattern (petaloid appearance) as shown below:

Topical antiprostaglandins and steroids are used in the management of CME. 

Other options:

Option B: Macular hole is the partial or full-thickness hole in the neurosensory retina. An OCT image of a full-thickness macular hole is shown below:

Option C: Central serous retinopathy is the spontaneous serous detachment of the neuroretina in the macular region with or without retinal pigment epithelium detachment.

Due to the altered permeability of the choroidal vascular system, there is an increase in the tissue hydrostatic pressure in the choroid. This causes a breach in the outer blood-retinal barrier. Leakage of fluid across this area causes detachment of the neurosensory retina. 

An OCT of central serous retinopathy showing neurosensory retinal detachment from the retinal pigment epithelium is given below:

Option D: Senile macular degeneration also known as age-related macular degeneration is a leading cause of blindness in the old age population. Extracellular deposits called drusens are deposited between retinal pigment epithelium and brush membrane.

In OCT drusens can be seen as hyperreflective irregular nodules and severe disruption of the external limiting membrane of the retina from choroid can be seen.

An OCT of age-related macular degeneration showing the separation of 10 layers including retinal pigment epithelium from the choroid is given below:

questions.text: A 2-year-old child was brought with complaints of regression of milestones and repeated wringing hand movements. On examination, there is microcephaly and a characteristic mousy odor in skin and urine. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a child presenting with regression of development, repetitive stereotypic behavior, microcephaly, and typical mousy odor in skin and urine is suggestive of phenylketonuria (PKU).

Phenylketonuria is an inborn error of metabolism, due to the deficiency of an enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase or its cofactor tetrahydrobiopterin. The deficiency of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of phenylalanine in the body fluids and the brain.

The excess phenylalanine in the blood is metabolized to phenyl ketones, namely, phenylpyruvate and phenylacetate, which are excreted in the urine and are termed phenylketonuria. Phenylacetate gives rise to the characteristic mousy odor in the skin and urine in PKU.

Infants appear normal at birth. They gradually develop an intellectual disability, and hyperactivity with autistic behavior as age progress. 

Other characteristic clinical findings are:

  • Seizures
  • Tremor
  • Microcephaly
  • Deficiency of pigmentation

Tandem mass spectroscopy is the screening method of choice. A low phenylalanine diet is the mainstay of treatment and keeping serum phenylalanine under 6 mg/dl.

Other options:

Option A- Alkaptonuria is an inborn error of metabolism due to the deficiency of an enzyme homogentisate 1,2 dioxygenase, leading to the accumulation of homogentisic acid in connective tissue resulting in ochronosis. Due to the oxidation and polymerization of homogenetic acid, it shows a characteristic blackening of urine on standing for a long time or black stain in diapers. They often present in the third to the fourth decade of life. 

Option C- Hawkinsinuria is an autosomal-dominant condition due to deficiency of an enzyme 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase which catalyzes the reaction of 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate to homogentisic acid in the tyrosine catabolism pathway. It leads to the accumulation of the metabolite hawkinsin. Most of the patients present during the weaning period with features of persistent metabolic acidosis and failure to thrive. The swimming pool odor of the urine is characteristic of this condition.

Option D- Tyrosinemia type 1 is an inborn error of metabolism due to deficiency of the enzyme fumarylacetoacetase. Most of the patients present at early infancy with symptoms suggestive of liver and renal dysfunction. The boiled cabbage odor of the urine is characteristic of this condition.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with complaints of right-sided facial weakness, tinnitus, dysphagia for 2 weeks, and progressive hearing loss for 2 years. A glomus tumor was suspected in this patient. Which of the following investigations will not be done for the above situation?
questions.solution:
In a clinical suspicion of a glomus tumor, a biopsy for histopathology is contraindicated.

Glomus tumor is an extremely vascular benign tumor. A preoperative biopsy is never done in glomus tumors as they bleed profusely, and there is an increased risk of injury to the high jugular bulb or aberrant internal carotid artery.

Glomus tumor is the most common benign neoplasm of the middle ear. It originates from the glomus bodies and consists of paraganglionic cells from the neural crest. It is a nonencapsulated tumor and a locally invasive tumor. 

Glomus tumor is most often seen in women in the fourth to fifth decade of life.

A patient typically presents with progressive conductive hearing loss, pulsatile tinnitus, dizziness, and facial paralysis. If the tumor presents as a polyp, a history of spontaneous bleeding from the ear is seen. 

Otoscopy examination shows a red reflex through an intact tympanic membrane as a "rising sun" appearance since the tumor arises from the floor of the middle ear as shown below:

Dysphagia and hoarseness of voice are present as late features due to IXth- XIIth cranial nerve paralysis.

Glomus tumors are of two types, glomus jugulare, which arises from the dome of the jugular bulb, and glomus tympanicum, which arises from the promontory of the middle ear. 

Glomus tumors are classified based on Fisch classification:

Class Extent 
Class A Tumor limited to the middle ear (mesotympanum)
Class B

Tumor limited to the middle ear (meso- and hypotympanum) and the mastoid
Class C

Tumor involving the infralabyrinthine compartment of the temporal bone and extending to the petrous apex
Class D

Intracranial extension. It can be intradural or extradural

Glomus tumors are paragangliomas, secreting catecholamines. This is diagnosed by testing the patient's 24-hour urine collection for urinary VMA (vanillylmandelic acid) or metanephrines. 

CT scan helps to distinguish the glomus tympanicum from the glomus jugulare and also to differentiate it from the aberrant carotid artery. MRI shows the soft tissue extends.

Four-vessel angiography shows the involvement of the jugular bulb, carotid artery, and intradural extension. It also helps to identify multiple glomus tumors and to find the feeding vessel of the tumor.

It can be removed surgically. Radiation and embolization can be used to reduce vascularity.

questions.text: You were posted for an autopsy of a 34-year-old man who was under police custody for interrogation. On external examination, signs of third-degree torture were present. Which of the following incisions is preferred to detect and evaluate the hidden subcutaneous hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of custodial death. The incision that is preferred to detect and evaluate the hidden subcutaneous hemorrhage is the elongated X- shaped incision.

An elongated X-shaped incision is used to dissect subcutaneous structures in the back of the body. It helps identify and evaluate the extent of blunt injuries when superficial imprints are faint. This type of incision is helpful in the reconstruction of events before death and is practiced in custodial death.

The image below shows the 'elongated X- shaped' incision:


Option A: I-shaped incision is a simple, convenient, and most commonly practiced incision. It extends from the symphysis mentii to the symphysis pubis, taking a curve towards the left or right around the umbilicus. The umbilicus has dense fibrous tissue and is difficult to penetrate with the needle for suturing after autopsy.

The image below shows the 'I- shaped' incision:


Option C: Y-shaped incision commences at anterior axillary fold on the chest on either side, runs downwards and anteriorly beneath the breasts as to meet at the xiphisternum in the midline and then run downwards to the symphysis pubis, as in the I-shaped incision. It is preferred in females. It is more cosmetically accepted as the incision, and the stitches are minimally seen after the autopsy. 

The image below shows the 'Y-shaped' incision:


Option D: In the modified Y-shaped incision, an incision is made in the midline from the suprasternal notch to the symphysis pubis. The incision extends from the suprasternal notch over the clavicle to its center on both sides and then passes upwards over the neck behind the ear. It is indicated in cases of strangulation or death due to compression of the neck.

The image below shows the 'modified Y-shaped' incision:

Related Pearl: Autopsy: Types Of Incision

Type of incision Procedure Indication Advantage
I-Shaped Incision Extends from symphysis menti to symphysis pubis, taking a curve towards the left around the umbilicus. It is used routinely in practice It is simple and convenient.
Y-Shaped Incision Commences at the acromial process on the shoulder on either side of the chest, runs downwards and anteriorly beneath the breasts as to meet at the xiphisternum and then run downwards as in the "I"-shaped incision   Preferred in females It prevents cutting of the chest skin in the midline.
Modified Y-Shaped Incision Commences at the angle of mandible on either side, brought forwards, downwards to meet at the suprasternal notch . It is then run downwards as a midline incision up to the pubic symphysis. Preferred when a detailed study of neck structures required, e.g. asphyxial death due to neck compression.  It has better exposure and allows the study of neck structures. 
Elongated X-shaped Incision Used to dissect out subcutaneous structures in the back to identify and evaluate the extent of blunt injuries.  Should be practiced in cases of custodial death.  Helpful in the reconstruction of events prior to death.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old patient presents with a severe left-sided excruciating headache for the past 30 minutes. He has experienced similar headaches every day at the same time for one week and these episodes last for an hour. Most episodes are accompanied by rhinorrhea. There are no cutaneous triggers. It does not respond to indomethacin and is triggered by alcohol. What is the likely diagnosis?

SUNCT: Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks with conjunctival injection and tearing
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of migrainous neuralgia or cluster headache. 

A male patient presenting with recurrent excruciating pain for 30 minutes, presence of autonomic features, aggravating on alcohol consumption, no cutaneous triggers, and no effect on indomethacin are points in favor of cluster headache. The typical cluster headache patient has daily one or two attacks of shorter duration unilateral pain for 8- 10 weeks per year. Cluster headaches are predominantly seen in males. Cluster headache is associated with autonomic features like conjunctival injection, lacrimation, and rhinorrhea. 

Cluster headache is a rare type of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia. Usually present with excruciating, non-fluctuating, retro-orbital pain.

Periodicity is the characteristic feature of cluster headaches. Usually, one of the daily attacks of pain recurs at about the same time each day. They last for a few weeks followed by a remission for months to years. 

Patients are usually agitated or aggressive during attacks. This is in contrast with migraine patients who remain motionless during the attack. 

Acute attacks are managed by 100% oxygen at 10 - 12 L/min for 15 -20 minutes. Subcutaneous sumatriptan 6mg has a rapid onset and will shorten the attack. Verapamil is used as a first-line treatment for prophylaxis.

Other options:

Option B: Paroxysmal hemicrania is a type of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia. They usually present as unilateral, frequent, excruciating short-lasting episodes of headache. They are completely relieved by indomethacin. 

Option C: SUNCT is a type of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia. They usually present as unilateral, severe, throbbing pain in the temporal or orbital region. They are always associated with cutaneous triggers. 

Option D: Tension headache is a chronic headache with the characteristic of a bilateral tight band-like discomfort.

  • Hemicrania continua

questions.text: A 3-day old male neonate who has not yet passed meconium developed abdominal distension. There is no history of fever. On rectal examination, forceful expulsion of stool was observed. A barium enema is performed and the findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the gold standard for the diagnosis of the above condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a male newborn presenting with failure to pass meconium, abdominal distension, forceful expulsion of stools on rectal examination, and barium enema showing dilated right colon with a transition zone in the mid descending colon is suggestive of Hirschsprung's disease. The gold standard for the diagnosis of Hirschprung's disease is a rectal biopsy.

In Hirschprung's disease, the rectal biopsy shows absent ganglia, hypertrophied nerve trunks, and positive immunostaining for acetylcholinesterase.

Hirschprung's disease is caused by malformation of the pelvic parasympathetic system that results in the absence of ganglion cells in the Auerbach and Meissner plexus. This causes muscular spasms of the distal colon and internal anal sphincter resulting in their functional obstruction. 

They are predominantly seen in boys and are often associated with Down syndrome. Most cases present during the neonatal period as abdominal distension, bilious vomiting, and failure to pass meconium. Beyond this period, they mainly present with poor feeding, abdominal distension, and severe constipation. Forceful expulsion of stools is observed on rectal examination as the stools were accumulated in the distal colon.

A barium enema is obtained on all suspected cases of Hirschprung's disease. This demonstrates the location of the transition zone between the dilated ganglionic colon and the distal aganglionic rectal segment. 

In older children, anorectal manometry shows a high internal sphincter pressure when the lumen of the rectum is distended with a balloon. This is due to the absence of normal inhibitory reflex in Hirschsprung's disease. But due to relative inaccuracy of findings, this test is not commonly done. 

Ultrasound findings may also suggest the diagnosis but it is not sensitive enough to exclude Hirschsprung's disease.

The three definitive surgical procedures are the Swenson procedure, Duhamel procedure, and Soave's procedure.

The most common cause of death in uncorrected Hirschprung's disease is enterocolitis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the OPD with complaints of fever with chills, headache, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. He gives a history of consuming stale food the previous day. Organism isolated on stool culture showed tumbling motility at 25°C and was non-motile at 37°C. Which among the following is the selective media for the above causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an adult with symptoms of gastroenteritis, history of consumption of stale food, organism showing tumbling motility at 25°C is suggestive of food poisoning caused by Listeria monocytogenes. The selective media for Listeria monocytogenes is PALCAM agar.

The PALCAM agar is used to isolate Listeria monocytogenes. They show a grey-green with a black sunken center and a black halo on a cherry-red background. Stool culture is done in cold enrichment media. 

Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive bacillus. It shows characteristic tumbling motility at 25°C and becomes non-motile at 37°C. The image below shows the tumbling motility of Listeria.

 

Listeria can overcome the food preservation process since it grows at 4°C, low pH, and high salt concentration. 

Listeriosis can present as gastroenteritis in healthy adults. It usually develops within 48 hours of ingestion of a large inoculum in contaminated food like raw sprouts, unpasturized milk or soft cheeses. It can also lead to the formation of abscess, pharyngitis, pneumonia, and endocarditis. It leads to neonatal meningitis and sepsis, and meningoencephalitis in the elderly and immunocompromised people. Listeriosis in pregnancy can lead to abortion and stillbirth.

The virulence factor produced by Listeria is called listeriolysin O. This helps the bacteria to escape and causes septicemia. They are catalase-positive, will not produce H2S, and shows beta hemolysis. This helps to differentiate Listeria from other gran positive bacilli.

It is treated with ampicillin and gentamicin.

Other options:

Option A- PLET medium is used to culture Bacillus anthracis.

Option C- PPLO broth is used to culture Mycoplasma pneumonia

Option D- Cary Blair medium is used as a transport medium of Vibrio cholera, and Campylobacter.

questions.text: The neonatology intern on ward duty noticed that a newborn's mother was unimmunized during pregnancy. What is the dose of antitoxin to be administered to this newborn for the prevention of neonatal tetanus?
questions.solution:
750 IU of antitoxin is administered to this newborn for the prevention of neonatal tetanus.

The infants born to mothers who have not received the 2 doses of tetanus toxoid during pregnancy have a risk of developing neonatal tetanus. They can be protected from this by administering 750 IU of antitoxin within 6 hours of birth.

In unimmunized pregnant women, two doses of tetanus toxoid are administered. First dose as early as possible and the second dose one month later. The second dose should be administered at least 3 weeks before delivery.

In previously immunized pregnant women, a booster dose is sufficient. Tetanus toxoid protects both mother and child from tetanus.

Tetanus is an acute disease caused by the exotoxin of Clostridium tetani. It is characterized by muscular rigidity and paroxysmal spasms of voluntary muscles. 

Related Pearl: Post exposure prophylaxis for tetanus

Prophylaxis is given based on patient category:

A. Full immunization or a booster dose within the past 5 years.

B. Full immunization or a booster dose > 5 years ago but < 10 years.

C. Full immunization or a booster dose > 10 years ago.

D. Unknown or never taken immunization

Category Clean wound Unclean wound
A Only wound care Only wound care
B Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose
C Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose + Human tetanus immunoglobulin 
D Wound care + TT complete course Wound care + TT complete course + Human tetanus immunoglobulin

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding the procedure shown below?

POG- Period of gestation

choices.text: Can be used in fetus with gestational age less than 34 weeks
Can be used in cases of fetal coagulopathy
Can be used for both vertex and face presentations
Flexion point is 3 cm in front of posterior fontanelle

questions.solution:
The above image shows a vacuum-assisted delivery. The flexion point is about 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanelle. 

A vacuum extractor is an instrument used in operative vaginal delivery by creating a vacuum between it and the fetal scalp. During vacuum-assisted delivery, the suction cup is placed on the fetal head at a point near the occiput, called the flexion point. A flexion point is an imaginary point on the sagittal suture, located about  6 cm from the center of the anterior fontanel or about 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanelle. The flexion point is closer to the posterior fontanelle.

Contraindications of vacuum delivery include:

  • Any presentation other than vertex (such as face/breech)
  • Preterm fetus (less than 34 weeks POG)
  • Suspected fetal coagulation disorder
  • Fetal macrosomia (more than 4 kg estimated weight)

Below is the image of vacuum extractor 

Traction should be abandoned if:

  • There is no decent of the presenting part with each pull
  • Delivery is not imminent after three pulls.

Under any circumstances, the traction should not exceed more than 30 minutes. 

An artificial caput succedaneum (chignon) is produced due to the sucking. It usually disappears within a few hours.

Vacuum delivery has reduced maternal pelvic floor injury, and it is the instrument of the choice in assisted delivery.

Vacuum-assisted vaginal deliveries may fail due to selection of incorrect cup size or accidental inclusion of maternal soft tissues within the cup or incorrect placement of the cup which results in malpresentation of the fetal head.

While in forceps deliveries, it is unlikely to detach from the fetal head and allows the fetal head for rotation. It can be used in premature fetuses and cause relatively less bleeding from the scalp. This makes forceps have a higher success rate as compared to vacuum-assisted delivery. 

Related Pearl: Vacuum delivery- indications and contraindications

Indications of ventouse:    

Therapeutic-

  • Fetal distress in second stage
  • Maternal distress in second stage
  • Prolonged second stage
  • Deep transverse arrest and persistent occipitoposterior
  • High vacuum for second twin

Prophylactic-

  • Preeclampsia
  • VBAC
  • Cardiac defects
  • Anemia

Contraindications of ventouse:     

  • Preterm head
  • Face presentation         
  • Fetal coagulopathy
  • Fetal blood sampling

questions.text: Which of the following prostaglandin analog can be used in the treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension?
questions.solution:
Iloprost can be used in the treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension. 

Iloprost is a prostaglandin I2 (prostacyclin) analog. It is available in both inhaled and intravenous formulations. The inhaled formulation has a potent vasodilative action on the pulmonary circulation with less systemic vasodilation than other intravenous prostacyclins.

Other prostacyclin analogs used for pulmonary arterial hypertension are epoprostenol and treprostinil.

Other options:

Option B- Alprostadil (Prostaglandin E1) is used as a second-line drug for the treatment of erectile dysfunction. It can be given as an intracavernous injection or urethral suppository.

Option C- Dinoprostone (PGE2) is used for cervical ripening and induction of labor.

Option D- Travoprost (PGF2alpha) is used for treating glaucoma.

questions.text: A specimen of the posterior surface of the larynx is kept in an anatomy practical exam and a structure is marked with red. What would be the action of the structure?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the posterior view of the larynx and the marked muscle is the posterior cricoarytenoid. Its action is to abduct the vocal cords and open the glottis. The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is identified by its origin from the posterior surface of the cricoid. 

The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle arises from the posterior surface of the cricoid lamina and is attached to the upper and posterior surfaces of the muscular processes of the ipsilateral arytenoids. It is innervated by a branch of the recurrent laryngeal nerve. They are active in the production of unvoiced sounds.

The image below shows the intrinsic muscles of the larynx.

Related Pearl: Muscles of larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

  • All muscles are adductors, except PCA (an abductor)
  • All muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except cricothyroid (superior laryngeal nerve)

questions.text:
A 48-year-old employee presented to the ESI hospital with resting tremors, slowness of movements, depression, dementia, and a shuffling, short-stepping gait. He has been working in the same factory for the past 11 years and his monthly income is Rs 20,000. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the benefits he can avail of under the ESI Act?

ESI: Employees' State Insurance Act

choices.text: Outpatient care by a specialist and supply of drugs free of cost
An extended sickness benefit for 3 years.
Inpatient care by a specialist and supply of drugs free of cost

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a patient with Parkinson's disease. He can avail of the extended sickness benefit, which is payable only for 2 years (not 3 years) under the ESI Act. 

ESI act covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month. Employer contributes 3.25% of the total wage bill. An employee contributes 0.75% of wages. State and Central governments share medical expenditure in the ratio of 1:7.

Extended sickness benefit is payable for 2 years for a set of 34 diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.

Few important points to be known about the ESI Act:

Medical benefit comprises complete medical care including hospitalization, free of cost which includes:

  • Out-patient care
  • Supply of drugs and dressings
  • Specialist services in all branches of medicine
  • Pathological and radiological investigations
  • Domiciliary services
  • Antenatal, natal, and postnatal services
  • Immunization services
  • Family planning services
  • Emergency services
  • Ambulance services
  • Health-education
  • In-patient treatment.

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

questions.text: The sequence of the non-template strand in a DNA fragment is TAAAGC. The mRNA that will be transcribed from the anti-sense strand will have the following sequence______
questions.solution:
UAAAGC will be the sequence of mRNA produced from this fragment of DNA (the non-template strand, which is TAAAGC), while the template strand will have a complementary sequence of ATTTCG.

The non-template strand or, coding strand, or sense/plus strand in the DNA, will have the same sequence of the RNA that is produced, except that the non-template or coding strand has T in place of U. 

As all sequences are written in the 5′ to 3′ direction, unless otherwise specified, an RNA sequence of UAAAGC would correspond to a DNA sequence on the non-template strand of TAAAGC.

Both the non-template strand and RNA produced will be a complementary sequence to the template strand. Therefore, the template strand would be ATTTCG (written 5′ to 3′).

Note:

Template strand - known as minus or, antisense or non-coding strand.

Coding strand- known as plus or, sense or non-template strand.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient came to dermatology OPD with the clinical features shown in the image below. The likely diagnosis is ______.
questions.solution:
The given image shows bluish patchy skin lesions on the face in the region of the first and second branches of the trigeminal nerve and sclera which are suggestive of nevus of Ota.

Nevus of Ota is an extensive, bluish, patchy, dermal melanocytosis. A large number of elongated dendritic melanocytes can be seen scattered among collagen bundles mainly of the superficial dermis.

It affects the sclera and the skin adjacent to the eye. Distributed along with the first and the second branches of the trigeminal nerve.

Most lesions are present at birth or develop during the first year of life, increasing in size and number in subsequent years. Lesions are more common in females and in Asians.

Q‐switched laser systems are the first-line treatment, as they achieve higher rates of pigment clearing.

Other options:

Option A- Nevus of Ito appears as a  unilateral, blue‐greyish macular discoloration location in the area innervated by the posterior supraclavicular and lateral cutaneous brachial nerves- acromioclavicular region.

 

Option B- A compound nevus is an acquired melanocytic nevus. It is a slightly raised, oval, or round symmetrical papule. This nevus is also pigmented, with shades of brown according to the skin color of the patient.

 

Option D- Hypomelanosis of Ito refers to the skin abnormalities characterized by unusual unilateral or bilateral cutaneous macular hypopigmented whorls, streaks, and patches, corresponding to the lines of Blaschko. It is often associated with epilepsy and mental retardation.

questions.text: A car driver hit his right knee on the dashboard on the sudden application of the brake during a motor vehicle collision. He complains of pain and swelling in the right knee. On examination, there is an excessive backward movement of the tibia in relation to the femur on gently pulling the upper end of the tibia. However, the forward movement of the tibia in relation to the femur appears normal. What is the structure most likely to be injured?

choices.text: Both anterior and posterior cruciate ligaments

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a direct anterior blow to the knees such as dashboard injury and excessive backward movement in the posterior drawer test is suggestive of posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injury.

The initial symptoms are very similar to an ACL (anterior cruciate ligament) injury like the immediate swelling. On performing the posterior drawer test, there would be excessive backward movement of the tibia in relation to the femur. The majority of patients with an isolated PCL injury will return to a high level of function with just appropriate quadriceps rehabilitation, without the need for surgical intervention.

On performing the anterior drawer test, the normal forward gliding movement of the tibia in relation to femoral condyles is suggestive of apparently normal anterior cruciate ligaments. 

Dashboard injury can also lead to

  • Posterior hip dislocation
  • Acetabular fracture
  • Patellar fracture
  • Fracture of neck of the femur
  • The shaft of femur fracture
  • Posterior cruciate ligament injury

The image below is an MRI of the knee joint, and the arrow shows the posterior cruciate ligament.

It is also called O'Donoghue's triad/ terrible triad/ horrible triad of the knee. It mostly occurs in football, basketball & rugby players, due to a lateral blow to the knee.

It is characterized by injury to:

  • Anterior cruciate ligament
  • Tibial collateral ligament

(Mnemonic – MAT)

questions.text:
A 33-year-old female patient presented with a 2-cm thyroid nodule. The results of thyroid function tests are within normal limits. FNAC of the nodule was done, and the findings are shown in the given image. Identify the incorrect statement regarding this condition.

FNAC - Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology

choices.text: Exposure to ionizing radiation is causative.

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and histopathological slide showing epithelial cells with clear ground-glass or Orphan Annie–eye nuclei are suggestive of the diagnosis of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Papillary thyroid cancers usually have an excellent prognosis.

Papillary carcinoma thyroid has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate of around 95%. The prognosis of papillary thyroid cancer is poor when age is more than 40 years, in the presence of extrathyroidal extension, and in the presence of distant metastases.

Papillary carcinoma thyroid (PTC) is the most common thyroid cancer. It is frequently associated with exposure to ionizing radiation. A gain-of-function mutation in BRAF is commonly seen in papillary thyroid cancer. Translocations that result in gene fusions of RET or NTRK are also seen in the PTC. 

Metastasis usually occurs via the lymphatic route, but hematogenous metastasis is less common. PTCs appear as cold masses on thyroid scintigraphy.

Microscopic features of papillary thyroid carcinoma:

  • The carcinoma shows branching papillae with fibrovascular stalk covered with simple or stratified cuboidal epithelium.
  • At high power, the nuclei appear optically clear or empty as the chromatin is dispersed. These empty-appearing nuclei are called Orphan Annie–eye nuclei.
  • Concentric calcified structures called psammoma bodies are usually seen.
  • Foci of lymphatic invasion by the tumor are usually present.

The presence of Orphan Annie-eye nuclei is diagnostic of papillary thyroid cancer, regardless of the presence of papillary architecture.

Variants of papillary carcinoma thyroid:

  1. Tall cell variant - Occurs in older people. Tall columnar cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm. The presence of BRAF mutations is diagnostic of this variant. They present with a higher rate of vascular invasion, extrathyroidal extension, and cervical and distant metastases than conventional PTC.
  2. Diffuse sclerosing variant - Occurs in younger individuals. This variant lack BRAF mutations, but RET/PTC translocations are present. There is a prominent papillary growth pattern with nests of squamous metaplasia. There is extensive, diffuse fibrosis throughout the thyroid gland, associated with lymphocytic infiltrate, simulating Hashimoto thyroiditis.
  3. Follicular variant - It has the characteristic nuclear features of papillary carcinoma and an almost totally follicular architecture. Contrasting to conventional PTC, this variant has a gain-of-function mutation of RAS.

The image below shows psammoma bodies in the papillary carcinoma thyroid. Inset shows a single concentrically calcified psammoma body.

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

questions.text: Which of the following factors can decrease the secretion of growth hormone?
questions.solution:
Obesity can decrease the secretion of growth hormone due to free fatty acid suppression of growth hormone.

Stimuli that affect growth hormone secretion in humans include,

Stimuli that increase secretion Stimuli that decrease secretion
  • Exercise
  • Deep sleep
  • Fasting/Hypoglycemia
  • Stressful stimuli (including various psychological stresses)
  • Protein deficiency
  • Ghrelin
  • Estrogens and androgens
  • Glucose
  • Aging
  • Obesity
  • FFA (free fatty acid)
  • Somatostatin
  • Growth hormone (exogenous)

The image given below depicts the fluctuations of secretion of growth hormone throughout the day. 

  • Growth hormone is found at relatively low levels during the day unless specific triggers such as strenuous exercise are present.
  • During sleep, on the other hand, large pulsatile bursts of growth hormone secretion occur.

questions.text: A male patient was diagnosed with schizophrenia for which he was treated with chlorpromazine and olanzapine for a month each. Despite treatment with two different antipsychotics, the symptoms still persist. Which drug is recommended to be used next in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with poor response to two antipsychotics is suggestive of resistant schizophrenia, and the drug that is recommended to be used next is clozapine.

Treatment-resistant schizophrenia refers to the failure to respond to at least two trials of antipsychotics of adequate dose and duration. A 4-6 week of antipsychotic on an adequate dose is considered an adequate trial. If patients show even a mild amount of improvement during this period, it may be reasonable to wait before changing a medication, since patients may improve at a steady rate for 3 to 6 months.

Clozapine, a second-generation antipsychotic (atypical antipsychotic) is used for patients who respond poorly to dopamine receptor antagonists (typical antipsychotic). It has mixed 5HT2A-D2 receptor antagonism. Other uses of clozapine are tardive dyskinesia, refractory mania, psychotic depression, and Huntington's disease.

Adverse effects of clozapine include sedation, agranulocytosis, weight gain, and postural hypotension. It is also associated with an increased risk of seizures.

Other options:

Option A: Chlorpromazine is a first-generation antipsychotic drug used in schizophrenia as a first-line agent.

Option B: Fluphenazine is a first-generation antipsychotic drug. It is used in schizophrenia and acute mania.

Option C: Quetiapine is a second-generation antipsychotic drug used in schizophrenia, acute mania, and bipolar depression.

questions.text: While performing bone grafting, which of the following instruments would you use to elevate the periosteum?
questions.solution:
The instrument used in the elevation of the periosteum is a periosteal elevator shown in image A.

It is used to elevate the periosteum, as nerves and vessels are generally on this plane, and once elevated there is a safer plane for surgery.

Option B: The image shows a curette used for curetting a cavity in the bone or removing fibrous tissue from the ends of a fracture. It is used in the management of enchondroma, GCT, and osteomyelitis.

Option C: The image shows an osteotome. It has both sides beveled and is used for cutting bone in surgeries such as McMurray's osteotomy and corrective osteotomy. 

Option D: It shows a bone gouge, a concave-bladed chisel used for cutting round bone surfaces or making holes in the bone.
